The solid-state catalyst-mediated oxidation of alkyl lactate produced from biomass to alkyl pyruvate is an intriguing approach to manufacture valuable resources compounds. In this study, several types of SBA-15/Zn/Ni catalysts containing different nickel loadings have been developed and used in a molecular oxygen environment to oxidize ethyl lactate (EL) compound to ethyl pyruvate (EP). The aforementioned catalyst was comprehensively characterised by employing XRD, ICP, FTIR, N2 physisorption, NH3-TPD, HR-SEM and HR-TEM. As more of nickel was loaded onto the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalyst, the EL conversion improved, but the selectivity of EP consistently exceeded greater than 95 %, regardless of the 15 % nickel loading. Assuming maximum conditions for the reaction (90 °C, 2 h in O2) over the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalyst, the selectivity of 99.5 % for EP and a conversion of 97.7 % for EL were achieved. A selectivity of 99.5 % for EP and a conversion of 97.7 % for EL were achieved. The catalytic combination of SBA-15 and Zn/Ni exhibited a significant reducing capacity due to the significant connection between both of them, as demonstrated by the NH3-TPD data. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Continuous processing Selective oxidation Ethyl lactate Ethyl pyruvate Zn/Ni Mesoporous SBA-15 Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction The growing interest in the catalytic transformation of bio-based feedstocks into products with enhanced value is driven by the exhaustion of fossil fuels along with the environmental worsening state [1]. A vital chemical intermediary, alkyl pyruvate is utilised in a wide range of goods, such as medicines, amino acids, carbohydrates, and polymers [2]. The dehydrative decarboxylation of tartaric acid forms the basis for the traditional and commercial manufacturing of alkyl pyruvate. On the other hand, the excessive use of KHSO4 as a dehydrating agent also contributes to environmental pollution [3-4]. The establishment of a sustainable and efficient method for alkyl pyruvate production is necessary [5]. Alkyl lactate is directly catalytically oxygenated for the formation of alkyl pyruvate represents a highly promising alternative to the current dehydration decarboxylation process [6]. This approach holds considerable potential because alkyl lactates are more atomically efficient to oxidize than alkyl pyruvates due to their closely analogous structural composition. Moreover, it is feasible to produce alkyl lactates at a low cost by fermenting various biomass sources [1,7-8]. Extensive research was accomplished on the alkyl lactate oxidative transformation to alkyl pyruvate, in both the liquid and gaseous phases, utilizing numerous catalysts that are solid in nature [9-10]. To boost activity, many Mo, Fe, and V-based catalysts with high reaction temperatures (>200 °C) were designed for this reaction in the gas phase [10-11]. The product could over oxidize and cause esters to hydrolysed as a result of the elevated temperature, which could decrease the alkyl pyruvate selectivity [12-13]. Alkyl lactate conversion into alkyl pyruvate was achieved efficiently in the liquid state, under favourable conditions [14]. Furthermore, this procedure demonstrated extraordinary alkyl lactate conversions, coupled with excellent selectivity for alkyl pyruvate [15]. However, under mild conditions, noble-metal catalysts are typically necessary to activate O2 [16]. In a recent study by Yin et al., Methyl lactate's performance and selectivity for methyl pyruvate were evaluated using noble-metal catalysts under identical conditions. Ru/AC demonstrated superior selectivity (90 %) for methyl pyruvate and a 19.4 % conversion of methyl lactate. On the other hand, the preference for simpler and cost-effective catalysts is favoured due to the exorbitant price of catalysts made out of precious metals for this process [17-18]. Various studies on transition metal-based catalysts pertaining to liquid phase specific oxidation of alkyl lactate have been conducted. Zhou et al. [19]. Emphasized the efficiency of TS-1 as a catalyst for converting EL into EP using aqueous H2O2 as the oxidant [20]. They achieved a complete conversion and the EP yield was found to be 97.8 % at 50 °C within 9 h [21]. Their study emphasized the role of Ti (OOH) active species in influencing the reaction rate [22]. Furthermore, under very mild conditions, heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts like V2O5 and VO (acac)2 have proven effective in catalysing the transformation of EL into EP incorporating TBHP as an oxidizing agent. In addition to H2O2 and TBHP, researchers frequently utilize O2, a natural and cost-effective oxidant, in various oxidation processes [23]. At 50 °C, Meng et al. achieved the EL conversions reached to 78 % and the EP selective ability remained 95 % in nitromethane using Na-doped OMS-2 catalysts, enhancing EP selectivity by reducing surface oxygen vacancies [24]. Vanadium-based catalysts like VOx/C, V2O5/g-C3N4, and meso‑VTN have also been utilised molecular oxygen as an oxidant in the process of alkyl lactate conversion into alkyl pyruvate. While solid catalysts are used, opportunities exist to improve EP selective ability through competing reaction mitigation (Scheme 1 ), develop cost-effective catalysts, and reduce reaction time and temperature [25]. The Table 1 . shows comparative of catalytic performances in the selective oxidation of ethyl lactate (EL) to ethyl pyruvate (EP) over various catalysts with conversion, selectivity and yield. Comparing with the previous research the novelty of this work is to open up the new avenue of bimetallic catalyst to attain 98.5 % EL conversion and 99.5 % EP Selectivity. The solid-state catalyst-mediated oxidation of alkyl lactate produced from biomass to alkyl pyruvate is an intriguing approach to manufacture valuable resources compounds. In this study, several types of Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalysts containing different nickel loadings have been developed and used in a molecular oxygen environment to oxidize ethyl lactate (EL) compound to ethyl pyruvate (EP). The purpose of this endeavour is to explore supported Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalysts with a range of Ni/Zn/SBA-15 (with ratios of Ni are 5,10,15, and 20), assess the implications of the catalytic capabilities for the oxidation of ethyl lactate (EL) to ethyl pyruvate (EP) in the liquid phase formulation and explore the catalyst's nature and the prospect of reusability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Pluronic P123, HCl were purchased from Marck Life Science Pvt. LTD, Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), Zinc sulphate monohydrate (ZnSo4.H2O), Nickel chloride (NiCl2·6H2O) were purchased from SD fine-chem LTD. We bought ethanol, hydrogen peroxide, hydrochloric acid (HCl), orthophosphoric acid (H3PO4), sulfuric acid (H3SO4), and hydrochloric acid from Sigma Aldrich. We bought ethyl pyruvate from Rankem. 2.2 Synthesis of SBA-15 The process for fabricating SBA-15 material was commenced initially by dissolving 24 gs of Pluronic P123 in 800 millilitres of double-distilled water under constant stirring at 31 °C by maintaining this condition for 2 h. Subsequently, a solution consisting of 150 millilitres of 30 % Con-HCl and 30 millilitres of TEOS was gradually introduced and blended into the mixture. The last blend was then constantly agitated at a consistent temperature for 20 h. Following this, the mixture was allowed to mature at 100 °C for an additional duration of 24 h. Afterwards, the white precipitate formed was subjected to filtration and collection, and then dried for an extra 24 h. Finally, the dried substance underwent calcination in a furnace at a temperature of 570 °C in an air environment, with this process lasting for 4 h [32]. 2.3 First of doping metal Doping 10 % of Zn to SBA-15, taking ZnSO4 about g and grained well with the help of mortal. Then it is dissolved in 30 mL of double-distilled water and stirred for 1hr and after SBA-15 is doped. Stirring for 2 h, then dried in a Hot Air oven for overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 4 hrs. It is grained as a fine powder and stored in an airtight vessel. 2.4 Second doping of metal SBA-15/Zn is divided into four portions. NiCl2 is taken and weighted in four different ratios (5 %, 10 %, 15 %, 20 %). It is grained well with the help of mortal. It is stirred with the required amount of water for 2 h. Then SBA-15/Zn is doped and stirred for 2hr. It is subsequently calcined for four hours at 500 °C and cured for a whole night in a hot air oven. Then the sample is grained to fine powder with the help of a mortal and stored in an air-tight vessel. Scheme S1 depicts a schematic illustration of the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 synthesis. 2.5 Overview of the reactor assembly The scientific investigations were executed in down flow approach in high-pressure stainless steel processors (fixed bed) with an inner diameter of 6 mm. The catalyst was usually used undiluted, approximately 3.6 g (size 1–2 mm). Scheme S2 provides a schematic representation of the high-pressure zones in the fixed-bed microreactor constructed for this investigation. The structure of the flow schematic contains three different zones: The first component of the diagram (right side) comprises the feed input lines; the second segment (middle section) has the eight-port valve and processor`s reactor chamber; whereas the final segment (left side) includes the final outcome of condensation and exhaust gases. The first part has feed check valves, mass flow controls and line filters, which regulate gas stream. The liquid reactant is transported via a pump over a second inlet pipe that is next to the gas lines, and subsequently meets an eight-port regulator and processor. An eight-port valve located adjacent to the hot oven in the focal point of the processor enables the feed stuff to be pumped into it. Administering the vaporized input blend or output via an online gas chromatograph is another advantage of this approach. The temperature sensor and regulator function together to regulate the temperature in the processor`s chamber and to observe the ambient temperature of the metal catalytic bed. The interior temperature of the oven is regulated and recorded by a mass flow regulator; it tends to remain at approximately 90 °C. PG is an acronym for the pressure in the processor. The final segment comprises of the liquid condenser, drain valve, back-pressure regulator. high-pressure, and areas separator. 2.6 Analysis of catalytic capability The reactions were executed in a pre-set bed stainless steel processor by a down-flow approach, with an inner diameter of 6 mm (high pressure). The tiny (1–2 mm) catalyst has been dehydrated for six hours at 250 °C in CO2-free air. After that, the processor had cooled down for one hour at conventional pressure as well as 90 °C. The substance to be fed was pumped in provided the pressure, temperature, and airflow were at suitable levels. Industries implementing 3.6 g of catalyst and WHSV (h −1) witnessed the reactions, which proceeded at temperatures between the 70 and 100 °C and 10 bar pressures. A constantly flowing reactor has been filled with a solution containing 20 mmol of ethyl lactate. The output components were examined in a gas chromatograph equipped with a N2-filled SGE BPX70 capillary column and a flame ionization detector. 2.7 Specifics of the sample Thermo Nicolet 380 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of samples and ILs were compiled at room temperature, covering a spectral range of 4000–500 cm−1, and anhydrous KBr was employed as the reference criterion. The crystallographic properties of the substances were analyzed via Cu Kα (λ = 0.1541 nm) radiation with a diffraction magnitude of 2θ between 10 and 90° by employing an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku, Saudi). The topography of the specimen was examined using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100 F) to assess its dimension and topology. Surface areas of samples were measured through the BET tests with a Micromeritics porosimeter (ASAP-2020 HD88). A Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 exterior area of coverage analyzer was employed to acquire the information regarding N2 adsorption-desorption and porousness. While adopting the Barrett, Joyner, & Halenda (BJH) method for assessment, 0.2–0.3 g of catalyst were degassed. Temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) observations were executed out implementing a sensor for thermal conductivity over a 70 mg catalyst sample on a Micromeritics Auto Chem II chemisorption system. Although CO2 desorption is assessed in NH3-TPD considering the temperature is raised to 800 °C under 10 % CO2/He gas, NH3 absorption is tracked in H2-TPD up to 1000 °C under 10 % H2/He gas. Using a quadrupole gas chromatography (GC), the products were analyzed. 2.8 Data treatment The entire conversion of reactant (ethyl lactate) and the product's selectivity was estimated using both the beginning and the end concentrations of ethyl lactate retrieved through the GC findings for every one-hour period of reaction. The SBA-15 sample shows the normal characteristics anticipated of the specimen in question. Despite this, peak values drop after loading Zn and Ni, suggesting that consecutive impregnation and calcination have stripped the mesoporous structure of its structured nature. There is moreover a slight shift in the peaks positions in the direction of higher degrees. (Table I). Previous researchers proposed that the oxides deposition inside the apertures of SBA-15 could create such a change [33]. Particularly at low Zn and Ni-ion loading concentrations, it is likely that factors other than deposition within the pores are responsible for the peak shift (Fig. 1). The Debye-Scherrer equation was adopted to determine the average dimension of particles in the synthesized catalysts, namely: (a) Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (b) Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (c) Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and (d) Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15. L = 0.89 λ β cos θ The size of the crystals, denoted by L, can be determined based on the Bragg diffraction angle, θ, the X-ray wavelength of 1.54 Å, and the width of the observed peaks at half maximum, β. By fitting the observed peaks to two Gaussian distributions, the position and width of the peaks can be determined accurately enough for monochromatic CuKa radiation. The average crystallite diameters of (a Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (b) Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (c) Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and (d) Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 determined from the (111) diffraction peak were 27.4, 31.3, 34.1, and 35.3 nm, respectively. The typical size of the particles of The SBA-15 material zeolite increases when the Zn/Ni ratio rises, owing to an increase in nickel concentration in order on the SBA-15 zeolite framework. On average, the crystallite sizes of (a) Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (b) Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (c) Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and (d) Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 zeolites determined applying the Scherrer formula were 24.3, 26.6, 32.4, and 34.8 nm, respectively [34-35]. 3.2 Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopically analysis FT-IR, is the method of investigation applied to the functional group analysis. It falls between 4000 and 400 cm−1 under the mid-infrared range. Fig. 2 . displays the materials listed below: (a) Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (b) Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, (c) Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and (d) Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15. An FT-IR study has identified an important absorption maxima occurred in the wavelength of 3700 cm−1, corresponds to modes of extending the OH band. The 1630 cm−1 maxima are occurred by the symmetric stretching vibration of the Si-O-Si bond, highlighting the existence of the exterior silanol group. The signal at 1068 cm−1 is believed to be appeared by the Si-OH group`s stretching modes, indicating the existence of networks between NiO2 and SBA-15. The water molecules bending vibration is also incorporated into the framework and the water absorption of the materials accounted for the spectral band recorded at 1631 cm−1 [36]. 3.3 BET-Analysis Fig. 3 . depicts the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (BET) of Ni(5–20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalyst. The figure provides information on the catalyst surface and pore volumes. The introduction of bi-metals (Zn-Ni) into the catalyst results in a distortion in the system of a type H2 hysteresis loop, although the BET surface area is uniform [37]. The BET surface area and pore capacity of the four different catalysts are highlighted in Table 2 . Due to the presence of metals in the voids, the catalyst's pore volume and catalytic surface area decreased as the percentage of metal loading increased. This shift in metal depth causes a decline in the area of the catalytic surface and its pore volume. The size of the pores decreases as a result of this metal intrusion, from 690.12 m2/g to 0.680 m2/g and 610.23 m2/g, respectively [32–33]. This was due to a blockage in the pores caused by high metal loading, which also resulted in a reduction in pore size from 7.23 nm to 6.68 nm. The use of N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm helps in determining the structural characteristics of the catalyst at the end of the process [38]. 3.4 High resolution - SEM Analysis High-resolution SEM (HR-SEM) was employed to examine the morphologies of Zn-Ni / SBA-15 surface. The HR-SEM micrographs of Zn(10) – Fe (5, 10, 15 & 20)/SBA-15 are presented in Fig.4 a-d, respectively. According to the HR-SEM, the sphere-shaped particles of Ni/Zn/SBA-15 are sized uniformly, but are aggregated. Furthermore, the particles have an average grain size of less than 100 nm and are all highly crystalline. It has been observed that nanoparticles of metals in the Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, catalysts have agglomerated, but were uniform in the Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalyst. With an increase in the amount of nickel, the agglomeration decreased. This may lead to better adsorption and increased catalytic activity [39-40]. 3.5 HR-TEM analysis Fig. 5 a. depicts the structure of reduced Zn /Ni bimetallic catalysts using TEM images. The recognizable hexagon-shaped SBA-15 mesoporous avenues are easily observed, and they contain metallic elements either beneath or adjacent to the mesoporous substrates. These results corroborate the metallic extent on smaller scales that the XRD measurements indicated. The aforementioned result demonstrates that Ni and Zn particles are evenly dispersed throughout the catalytic support. This is the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 in Fig. 4d. The spread of particle sizes of the SBA-15 zeolite is narrow. The mean diameter of the particles of the SBA-15 material mesoporous structure in each of the four samples is 24–28, 26–29, 29–32, and 30–34 nm, respectively for Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15. The average particle size measured using HR-TEM pictures is consistent with the average crystallite size determined by the Debye-Scherrer formula from the pattern determined by XRD. Figs. 5a–d depict HR-TEM images of Ni(x)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 zeolites. The distributions of the particle sizes in the histograms of Ni/Zn/SBA-15 zeolites are displayed in the insets of Figure. 5a–d. Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 samples have average particle sizes of 24–28, 26–29, 29–32, and 30–34 nm. The surfactant-assisted preparation has a smaller average dimension of particles than the surfactant-free preparation that we synthesised. Based on the results presented above, we contend that Zn/Ni is crucial for creating particles that are smaller and exhibit less aggregation [41]. The HR-TEM investigation revealed that Ni/Zn metal was successfully integrated into the SBA-15-Zn/Ni mesoporous structure without changing the mesoporous SBA-15 structural integrity. On the SBA-15 surface, the average particle size of the SBA-15-Zn/Ni Fig.5b is close to 25 nm. 90 % of the particle size at 25 nm is shown by the catalysts (a)SBA15-Zn(10)/Ni(5), b)SBA15-Zn(10)/Ni(10), (c)SBA15-Zn(10)/Ni(15) and d)SBA15-Zn(10)/Ni(20). 80 % of the particle size in the SBA15-Zn(10)/Ni(20) range from 30 to 35 nm. This explains why the particle size on the SBA-15 increases as the metal loading increases [42-43]. 3.6 NH3-TPD analysis The acidity of Ni(5–20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalysts has been assessed through the NH3-TPD method. The appropriate TPD profiles for Ni(5–20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 are shown in Fig. 6 . The image displays two desorption peaks for the Ni(5–20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalyst, with the peaks occurring at 250 °C and 550 °C, respectively. There are two peaks in the ammonia desorption pattern of Ni(5–20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalysts. Ammonia is desorbing from weak acid sites, reflected by the low-temperature peak, and strong acid sites, as indicated by the peak appeared at high temperature zone. The trends of ammonium desorption are consistent across all cases under investigation. However, Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 has a greater peak intensity than Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15. Notably, Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 demonstrated low acid strength because of the low concentration of zinc and nickel in SBA-15 [44]. 4 Catalytic activity study's 4.1 Selective oxidative process of (EL) ethyl lactate Ethyl lactate was selectively oxidised in a perpetual reaction process with Ni(x)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 (Ni molar ratios (x) of 5, 10, 15, and 20 %). By studying the impacts of changes in reaction parameters pertaining to the pressure and temperature of the process (60–100 °C), the conversion of ethyl lactate and the selectivity of ethyl pyruvate were increased by altering the process parameters. Furthermore, for the WHSV experiment, the most readily reactive Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 batch was opted, and its capability as a further re-utilization was explored. 4.2 Investigation on impact of operating temperature Figs. 7 A and 7B exhibit the trended relationship between the convertibility, selectivity and relevance of processing temperatures in the oxidative process of EL to EP. Ni(x)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 metal catalyst, where x % is set to 5 %, 10 %, 15 %, and 20 %. Figs. 7A and 7B show the temperature shift from 60 to 100 °Celsius as part of the conversion and selectivity investigation. Fig. 7A depicts the conversion of two independent items. The initially manufactured product was ethyl pyruvate, with conversions ranging from 71 to 97.5 %. Pyruvic acid, a supplemental product, with an effective conversion of 1 % to 4.6 %. At 60 °C, 75.3 % conversion to ethyl pyruvate was achieved, and the conversion improved as the solution temperature rose to 90 °C. Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 showed the highest conversion of the four catalyst modifications, ranging from 75.2 % at 60 °C to 96.2 % at 90 °C. By contrast, maximum conversions of 92.4 and 99.4 % were obtained at Ni metal concentrations of 15 % and 20 %, respectively. The results show that increasing the amount of Ni by up to 20 % accelerated the pace at which ethyl lactate converted to ethyl pyruvate. Compared to 15 % Ni content, a 3.9 % decrease in conversion was seen with a 20 % Ni content increase. Furthermore, all four catalyst modifications showed a 5.4 % decline in conversion relative to their peak at 90 °C when the research's duration was raised to a process temperature of 100 °C. Temperatures above 90 °C cause conversion activity to slow down because the extra energy used leads to over-oxidation, which produces lactic acid, The selectivity of the final product during the conversion of ethyl lactate is shown in Fig. 7B. Once more, the investigation was carried out outside in temperatures between 60 and 100 °Celsius. The highest selectivity of 100 % had been attained, regardless of a lower operating temperature residing in 60 °C, demonstrating the catalyst's efficacy in lowering energy usage. The catalyst with the highest conversion and 99.5 % selectivity had a 15 % Ni concentration at 90 °C. The results of this inquiry cannot be compared to batch processing experiments reported in the literature because this is the first attempt to use an uninterrupted flow reaction. On the other hand, the conversion was significantly higher at temperatures below 90 °C than it was at 160 °C during sequential processing experiments. In the temperature-controlled investigation, response time was two hours, WHSV was kept at 1 h −1, and applied pressure was retained at 10 bars respectively. [45]. 4.3 Turnover frequency [TOF (s–1)] and specific reaction rate (r) Table 3 displays the calculated TOF in (s–1) along with the specific rate of the reaction (r) in (mole g −1 s −1) for ethyl lactate's oxidative process. When tested for the oxidation of ethyl lactate, Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalysts possess greater catalytic efficacy than equivalent Ni(x)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 (Ni(x) = 5, 10, 15 and 20). This is supported by higher turnover frequencies (TOF) and specific reaction rates (SRR) for EL, which are 4.78 and 4.44 of TOF in s −1 and 9.12 × 10−4 and 7.90 × 10−4 of SRR in mol g −1 s −1, respectively. This is a plausible justification for the catalyst's high activity and high conversion. In concluding, the SRR and TOF values of the Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalysts were found to be 4.11 and 3.91 of TOF in s −1 and 8.44 × 10−4 and 7.33 × 10−4 of SRR in mol g −1 s −1, respectively, showing an extremely low level of activity Perhaps there aren't having sufficient reactive spots on the catalyst to deal with this. The catalytic reactivity and conversion efficacy of the Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 substrates are superior to those of the other catalysts. Considering the catalytic reactivity of Ni(5)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(10)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15, and Ni(20)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 the TOF outcomes are compared to those published in prior research using Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalysts [46]. 4.4 Assessment on the impact of applied pressure The rate of convertibility and selectivity of ethyl lactate to ethyl pyruvate are influenced by reaction pressure, as seen graphically in Figs. 8 A and B. The process pressure ranged from 5 to 20 bar for the catalyst, which was composed of with Ni(x)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 (x) x: 5, 10, 15, and 20 % Ni content. As described in the temperature range of the study, the conversion to ethyl lactate ranged from 85 to 95 %, while pyruvic acid ranged from 0 to 10 %. The rate at which the conversion occurred increased, although gradually, as the pressure while growing from 5 to 15 bar. Every single one of the four catalysts increased conversion by roughly 5 %. Once more, the 15 % Ni catalyst converted 95.3 % at 10 bar, outperforming the other variations. However, all four catalysts displayed a decrease in conversion when the pressure was raised over 15 bar. The catalysts demonstrated a 3.5 % drop in activity at 20 bar process pressure. The results of selectivity for the applied air pressure range are depicted in Fig. 8B. Even at low pressures of 5 bar, 100 % selectivity was achieved, confirming the catalyst's processing efficiency. All four catalyst variations showed a decrease in selectivity as pressure increased. However, the 15 % Ni catalyst resulted in a smaller reduction of 6.2 %. In instance, 5 % and 10 % Ni catalysts showed significantly higher losses at 15 %, while 20 % Ni concentration in order resulted in a 20 % selectivity loss. In accordance with the study, 15 % of Ni was required to achieve a high degree of selectivity with regard to the applied range of pressure, while lower or higher concentrations of Ni metal resulted in less selectivity. During the continuous processing of this experiment, the bimetal catalyst's cooperative impact at a pressure of 10 bar for a 15 % Ni content showed an ideal maximum 94.6 % conversion and 99.5 % selectivity respectively. Once more, investigations on batch processing have shown that bimetal structure catalysts produce more products than monometals. The chemical procedure produced significant oxidation at pressures higher than 10 bar, which led to the synthesis of pyruvic acid (8 % conversion). The temperature was kept at 90 °C, the WHSV at 1h−1, and the processing time was 2 h for the pressure investigation. 4.5 Study on influence of WHSV The rate of convertibility and selectivity of ethyl lactate to ethyl pyruvate as a function of WHSV (h −1) are shown graphically in Figs. 9 A and B. In this work, the ethyl lactate starting material was changed from 0.5 to 2.0 h −1 of WHSV for the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 continuous reaction. The synthesized catalyst, referred as having a 15 % Ni concentration, was able to attain an unprecedented conversion at a 0.5 h −1 WHSV, although the conversions of the remaining variants were marginally less productive. The rate of convertibility of all four catalysts declined when WHSV raised from 0.5 h −1. The concentration of the 15 % Ni catalyst decreased by the smallest amount, 6.5 %, while the 5 % Ni catalyst reduced the greatest, 14.5 %. In contrast, the sensitivity study for WHSV variations found that the strongest selection occurred at 2.0 h −1 WHSV. Yet again, the Ni(15 %) catalyst competed each of the remaining catalysts, approximately with a 94.6 % selectivity for 0.5 h −1 WHSV and 99.5 % for 2.0 h −1 WHSV. At 0.5 h −1 WHSV, the remaining three catalysts had 18, 12, and 8 % product selectivity than the Ni catalysts (4, 6, and 10 %, correspondingly). The selectivity of the 5, 10, and 20 % catalysts, on the other hand, was only two to four percentage points lower than Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalyst when WHSV dropped to 2.0. The research study's maximum conversion efficiency of 99.5 % was reached at 0.5 h −1 WHSV; for instance WHSV was raised to 2.0 h −1, this efficiency somewhat declined. Convertibility enhanced at minimal WHSV specifies the existence of catalyst`s convertibility zones that help to oxidize ethyl lactate. On the other hand, pyruvic acid is produced upon severe oxidation at lower WHSV, which lowers selectivity. When WHSV was raised to 2.0 h −1, selectivity improved. The bimetal catalyst has a high conversion activity, as evidenced by the WHSV results, with 96.4 % optimal conversion and 97.8 % product selectivity, respectively. The reaction time was two hours, the working pressure was set to 10 bar, and the working temperature was kept at 90 °C. 4.6 Influence of reaction progressing time The convertibility and selectivity of EL into EP as a function of process time are shown in Fig. 10 A and B. In order to assess the convertibility and product selectivity of ethyl lactate, the reaction progressing duration was adjusted from two to ten hours. The Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 content catalyst had the maximum conversion of 99.5 % over a 2-hour operation, whereas the conversions of the other three catalysts ranged from 2 to 4 % lower. Nevertheless, the total conversion for the 15 % Ni catalyst decreased to 95 % when the reaction period was extended from two to ten hours. The catalysts with 5, 10, and 20 % Ni showed a noticeably sharper downward tendency. The conversion dropped to 16.5, 14.2, and 12.4 % for the 5, 10, and 20 % Ni catalysts, respectively, in relation to the 15 % Ni catalyst. Once more, lower conversion was attributed to Ni concentrations above 12 %. Selectivity results from the experiment were comparable; after two hours of processing, a 15 % Ni catalyst achieved the maximum selectivity of 100 %. At two hours, the selectivity percentages of the remaining three catalysts were all 2–4 % lower than the 15 % Ni catalyst. The study found that selectivity decreased as process reaction time grew from two to 10 h. At 10 h, the selectivity was 85.3, 86.7, 94.3, and 95.8 % for catalysts containing 10, 5, 20, and 15 % of Ni, respectively. The study shows how well energy was used in conjunction with the 15 % Ni catalyst that was used, which at two hours of reaction time had the highest conversion and selectivity. After two hours of reaction progressing time, the Ni(15)/Zn(10)/SBA-15 catalyst achieved 99 % convertibility and 100 % product selectivity. In order to guarantee complete transformation of reactants, reaction time is essential. This study's 100 % conversion and 2-hour selectivity indicate that the catalyst may deliver 100 % of the total yield in a brief amount of time. Lower conversion and selectivity are the result of over-oxidation, which happens when the reaction goes on for more than two hours. Similarly, after 8 h of reaction time, an 85.3 % yield was achieved in batch processing tests of ethyl lactate to ethyl pyruvate. The operating temperature was optimised at 90 °C, the applied pressure at 10 bar, with the rate of 1.0 h −1 WHSV for the response period of the time investigation. 4.7 Mechanism According to the catalytic results and previous reports [47-49], a probable catalytic mechanism was proposed (Fig. 11 ). Initially, the reactant Ethyl lactate adsorbs onto the Ni2+ ions on the catalyst's surface (step I), where the hydroxyl hydrogen atom is then chemisorbed through a coordinated bond, activating oxygen species (steps II and III). Subsequently, the β-hydrogen is captured by the lattice oxygen of the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalyst, forming a five-membered intermediate (step IV). This intermediate undergoes β-hydrogen elimination to produce Ethyl pyruvate and H2O, simultaneously creating an oxygen vacancy on the catalyst (steps V and VI). Finally, the oxygen vacancy on the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalyst is replenished by adsorbed oxygen, completing the catalytic cycle. In most oxidation reactions, lower oxidation state cations are essential for oxygen activation. 4.8 Reuse of catalyst study Table 4 . displays the results of a seven-cycle study on the catalyst's durability and recycle performance. Every conversion cycle showed a slight decrease in conversion, with a 1 % annual decline in conversion noted for every cycle in question. Following seven reaction cycle cycles, the percentage of conversion decreased from 99.6 to 93.4.7 %. Regarding the studies on selectivity, the selectivity decreased to 1 % for the sixth cycle and 3.5 % for the seventh cycle after remaining nearly constant for the first five cycles. The selectivity decreased to 96.2 % at the final stage of the seventh cycle, from 100 %. Throughout seven cycles, the procedure demonstrates the catalyst's robustness and stability by generating a yield that is approximately 98 %. In comparison to earlier batch processing studies, a high yield was made possible by the continuous process study's utilisation of the catalyst's comparatively high surface area (742.91 m2/g). The recycle study was carried out with a carefully monitored temperature of 90 °C, a controlled pressure of 10 bar, WHSV of 1.0 h −1, and a response period of 4 h. 5 Conclusions In conclusion, an environmentally friendly, cost-effective, and high-efficiency aerobic oxidation methodology is currently created to facilitate the manufacturing of necessary industrial chemicals which include ethyl pyruvate when there is a source of O2 which serves as the green oxidant in a continuous reactor. The impregnation approach has been implemented for developing Zn/Ni/SBA-15 catalysts containing variable nickel the loadings. In accordance with the characterization outcomes, the nickel oxide deposited on SBA-15 substrates had properly propagated, and the well-organized mesoporous structure of SBA-15 remained intact even after Zn/Ni loading. The newly synthesised SBA-15/Zn (10 %) / Ni(15 %) proven better catalytic capability for the oxidative procedure of ethyl lactate to ethyl pyruvate, offering 98.5 % ethyl lactate conversion and 99.5 % selectivity for ethyl pyruvate around 90 °C for a period of four hours while employing oxygen molecules as a green-oxidant, which is noticeably better than that of previously documented Ni catalysts to accomplish this recombinant outstanding catalytic effectiveness was attributed to the strong contact between Zn/Ni and SBA-15, particularly improved the reducibility of the SBA-15/Zn (10 %) / Ni (15 %) catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The solid-state catalyst-mediated oxidation of alkyl lactate produced from biomass to alkyl pyruvate is an intriguing approach to manufacture valuable resources compounds. In this study, several types of SBA-15/Zn/Ni catalysts containing different nickel loadings have been developed and used in a molecular oxygen environment to oxidize ethyl lactate (EL) compound to ethyl pyruvate (EP). The aforementioned catalyst was comprehensively characterised by employing XRD, ICP, FTIR, N2 physisorption, NH3-TPD, HR-SEM and HR-TEM. As more of nickel was loaded onto the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalyst, the EL conversion improved, but the selectivity of EP consistently exceeded greater than 95 %, regardless of the 15 % nickel loading. Assuming maximum conditions for the reaction (90 °C, 2 h in O2) over the Ni/Zn/SBA-15 catalyst, the selectivity of 99.5 % for EP and a conversion of 97.7 % for EL were achieved. A selectivity of 99.5 % for EP and a conversion of 97.7 % for EL were achieved. The catalytic combination of SBA-15 and Zn/Ni exhibited a significant reducing capacity due to the significant connection between both of them, as demonstrated by the NH3-TPD data.
